content.text:
# Draft:List of vice presidential trips made by Mike Pence

Thought for 2m 52s
This is a list of vice presidential trips made by Mike Pence, the 48th vice president of the United States from January 20, 2017, to January 20, 2021.
This list excludes trips made within Washington, D.C., the U.S. federal capital in which the Number One Observatory Circle, the official residence of the vice president, is located. Also excluded are trips to Camp David, the country residence of the president, as well as Joint Base Andrews. International trips are included.
The number of visits per state or territory he traveled are:
One: Colorado, Florida, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Texas
Two: Hawaii
2017
January
No trips.
February
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-

U.S. state

! width=550|Details
|-
| Maryland
| National Harbor
| February 23–24
| Vice President Pence delivered remarks at the Conservative Political Action Conference at the Gaylord National Resort & Convention Center.
|}
March
No trips.
April
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto"
|-
! width=120|Country/
U.S. state
! width=100|Areas visited
! width=70|Dates
! width=550|Details
|-
| South Korea
| Seoul
| April 15–17
| Vice President Pence arrived in Seoul, spent Easter Sunday with U.S. and Republic of Korea troops and their families, participated in a bilateral meeting with Acting President Hwang Kyo-ahn, met with National Assembly Speaker Chung Sye-kyun, participated in a listening session with local business leaders, and gave remarks to the business community. He condemned North Korea's missile launch and warned that the era of strategic patience is over.
|-
| Japan
| Tokyo
| April 18–19
| Vice President Pence met with Prime Minister Shinzō Abe, led the inaugural U.S.-Japan Economic Dialogue with Deputy Prime Minister Tarō Asō, participated in a listening session followed by remarks to the U.S. and Japanese business community, toured the USS Ronald Reagan, and gave remarks to U.S. and Japanese service members. He pledged cooperation on the Korean peninsula denuclearization.
|-
| Indonesia
| Jakarta
| April 20–21
| Vice President Pence met with President Joko Widodo and Vice President Jusuf Kalla, met with the ASEAN Secretary General and ASEAN Permanent Representatives to note the 40th Anniversary of US-ASEAN relations, participated in a listening session with U.S. and Indonesian business leaders, and gave remarks to the business community. He toured the Istiqlal Mosque and praised moderate Islam.
|-
| Australia
| Sydney
| April 22–23
| Vice President Pence met with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, met with Foreign Minister Julie Bishop and Opposition Leader Bill Shorten, met with U.S. and Australian service members, participated in a listening session and gave remarks to the U.S. and Australian business community. He affirmed U.S. intent to honor the refugee resettlement agreement.
|-
| Hawaii
| Honolulu
| April 24–25
| Vice President Pence met with senior leadership from the Pacific Command, visited the USS Arizona Memorial to pay honor to those who fought and perished during the attack on Pearl Harbor, and met with U.S. troops and their families. He cut short his stop in Hawaii to address domestic matters.
|}

2020
Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, many trips were virtual or canceled, with focus on campaign visits.
The number of visits per state or territory he traveled to:
One: Alaska, California, Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Texas, Utah, Wisconsin
